FedPAQ: A Communication-Efficient Federated Learning Method with Periodic Averaging and Quantization


 


Amirhossein Reisizadeh                        Aryan Mokhtari                        Hamed Hassani UC Santa Barbara                        UT Austin                        UPenn

Ali Jadbabaie                        Ramtin Pedarsani MIT                        UC Santa Barbara

Abstract

Federated learning is a distributed framework according to which a model is trained over a set of devices, while keeping data localized. This framework faces several systems-oriented challenges which include (i) communication bottleneck since a large number of devices upload their local updates to a parameter server, and (ii) scalability as the federated network consists of millions of devices. Due to these systems challenges as well as issues related to statistical heterogeneity of data and privacy concerns, designing a provably efficient federated learning method is of significant importance yet it remains challenging. In this paper, we present FedPAQ, a communication-efficient Federated Learning method with Periodic Averaging and Quantization. FedPAQ relies on three key features: (1) periodic averaging where models are updated locally at devices and only periodically averaged at the server; (2) partial device participation where only a fraction of devices participate in each round of the training; and (3) quantized message-passing where the edge nodes quantize their updates before uploading to the parameter server. These features address the communications and scalability challenges in federated learning. We also show that FedPAQ achieves near-optimal theoretical guarantees for strongly convex and non-convex loss functions and empirically demonstrate the communication-computation tradeoff provided by our method.

1 Introduction

In many large-scale machine learning applications, data is acquired and processed at the edge nodes of the network such as mobile devices, users’ devices, and IoT sensors. Federated Learning is a novel paradigm that aims to train a statistical model at the “edge” nodes as opposed to the traditional distributed computing systems such as data centers (Konečnỳ et al., 2016; Li et al., 2019a). The main objective of federated learning is to fit a model to data generated from network devices without continuous transfer of the massive amount of collected data from edge of the network to back-end servers for processing.

Federated learning has been deployed by major technology companies with the goal of providing privacy-preserving services using users’ data (Bonawitz et al., 2019). Examples of such applications are learning from wearable devices (Huang et al., 2018), learning sentiment (Smith et al., 2017), and location-based services (Samarakoon et al., 2018). While federated learning is a promising paradigm for such applications, there are several challenges that remain to be resolved. In this paper, we focus on two significant challenges of federated learning, and propose a novel federated learning algorithm that addresses the following two challenges:
(1) Communication bottleneck. Communication bandwidth is a major bottleneck in federated learning as a large number of devices attempt to communicate their local updates to a central parameter server. Thus, for a communication-efficient federated learning algorithm, it is crucial that such updates are sent in a compressed manner and infrequently.
(2) Scale. A federated network typically consists of thousands to millions of devices that may be active, slow, or completely inactive during the training procedure. Thus, a proposed federated learning algorithm should be able to operate efficiently with partial device participation or random sampling of devices.

The goal of this paper is to develop a provably efficient federated learning algorithm that addresses the above-mentioned systems challenges. More precisely, we consider the task of training a model in a federated learning setup where we aim to find an accurate model over a collection of n𝑛n distributed nodes. In this setting, each node contains m𝑚m independent and identically distributed samples from an unknown probability distribution and a parameter server helps coordination between the nodes. We focus on solving the empirical risk minimization problem for a federated architecture while addressing the challenges mentioned above. In particular, we consider both strongly convex and non-convex settings and provide sharp guarantees on the performance of our proposed algorithm.

Contributions. In this work, we propose FedPAQ, a communication-efficient Federated learning algorithm with Periodic Averaging and Quantization, which addresses federated learning systems’ bottlenecks. In particular, FedPAQ has three key features that enable efficient federated learning implementation:
(1) FedPAQ allows the nodes (users) of the network to run local training before synchronizing with the parameter server. In particular, each node iteratively updates its local model for a period of iterations using the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method and then uploads its model to the parameter server where all the received models are averaged periodically. By tuning the parameter which corresponds to the number of local iterations before communicating to the server, periodic averaging results in slashing the number of communication rounds and hence the total communication cost of the training process.
(2) FedPAQ captures the constraint on availability of active edge nodes by allowing a partial node participation. That is, in each round of the method, only a fraction of the total devices–which are the active ones–contribute to train the model. This procedure not only addresses the scalability challenge, but also leads to smaller communication load compared to the case that all nodes participate in training the learning model.
(3) In FedPAQ, nodes only send a quantized version of their local information to the server at each round of communication. As the training models are of large sizes, quantization significantly helps reducing the communication overhead on the network.

While these features have been proposed in the literature, to the best of our knowledge, FedPAQ is the first federated learning algorithm that simultaneously incorporates these features and provides near-optimal theoretical guarantees on its statistical accuracy, while being communication-efficient via periodic averaging, partial node participation and quantization.

In particular, we analyze our proposed FedPAQ method for two general class of loss functions: strongly-convex and non-convex. For the strongly-convex setting, we show that after T𝑇T iterations the squared norm of the distance between the solution of our method and the optimal solution is of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(1/T) in expectation. We also show that FedPAQ approaches a first-order stationary point for non-convex losses at a rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{T}). This demonstrates that our method significantly improves the communication-efficiency of federated learning while preserving the optimality and convergence guarantees of the baseline methods. In addition, we would like to highlight that our theoretical analysis is based on few relaxed and customary assumptions which yield more technical challenges compared to the existing works with stronger assumptions and hence acquires novel analytical techniques. More explanations will be provided in Section 4.

Related Work. The main premise of federated learning has been collective learning using a network of common devices such as phones and tablets. This framework potentially allows for smarter models, lower latency, and less power consumption, all while ensuring privacy. Successfully achieving these goals in practice requires addressing key challenges of federated learning such as communication complexity, systems heterogeneity, privacy, robustness, and heterogeneity of the users. Recently, many federated methods have been considered in the literature which mostly aim at reducing the communication cost. McMahan et al. (2016) proposed the FedAvg algorithm, where the global model is updated by averaging local SGD updates. Guha et al. (2019) proposed one-shot federated learning in which the master node learns the model after a single round of communication.

Optimization methods for federated learning are naturally tied with tools from stochastic and distributed optimization. Minibatch stochastic gradient descent distributed optimization methods have been largely studied in the literature without considering the communication bottleneck. Addressing the communication bottleneck via quantization and compression in distributed learning has recently gained considerable attention for both master-worker (Alistarh et al., 2017; Seide et al., 2014; Bernstein et al., 2018; Smith et al., 2016) and masterless topologies (Reisizadeh et al., 2019a; Zhang et al., 2018; Koloskova et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019). Moreover, Wang et al. (2019) reduces the communication delay by decomposing the graph.

Local updates, as another approach to reduce the communication load in distributed learning has been studied in the literature, where each learning node carries out multiple local updates before sharing with the master or its neighboring nodes. Stich (2018) considered a master-worker topology and provides theoretical analysis for the convergence of local-SGD method. Lin et al. (2018) introduced a variant of local-SGD namely post-local-SGD which demonstrates empirical improvements over local-SGD. Wang and Joshi (2018) provided a general analysis of such cooperative method for decentralized settings as well.

Statistical heterogeneity of users’ data points is another major challenge in federated learning. To address this heterogeneity, other methods such as multitask learning and meta learning have been proposed to train multiple local models (Smith et al., 2017; Nichol et al., 2018; Li et al., 2019b). Many methods have been proposed to address systems heterogeneity and in particular stragglers in distributed learning using coding theory, e.g., (Lee et al., 2018; Yu et al., 2017; Dutta et al., 2016; Tandon et al., 2016; Reisizadeh et al., 2019b). Another important challenge in federated learning is to preserve privacy in learning (Duchi et al., 2014). McMahan et al. (2017); Agarwal et al. (2018) proposed privacy-preserving methods for distributed and federated learning using differential privacy techniques. Federated heavy hitters discovery with differential privacy was proposed in (Zhu et al., 2019).

Robustness against adversarial devices is another challenge in federated learning and distributed learning that has been studied in (Chen et al., 2017; Yin et al., 2018; Ghosh et al., 2019). Finally, several works have considered communication-efficient collaborative learning where there is no master node, and the computing nodes learn a model collaboratively in a decentralized manner (Reisizadeh et al., 2019a; Zhang et al., 2018; Doan et al., 2018; Koloskova et al., 2019; Lalitha et al., 2019). While such techniques are related to federated learning, the network topology in master-less collaborative learning is fundamentally different.

2 Federated Learning Setup

In this paper, we focus on a federated architecture where a parameter server (or server) aims at finding a model that performs well with respect to the data points that are available at different nodes (users) of the network, while nodes exchange their local information with the server. We further assume that the data points for all nodes in the network are generated from a common probability distribution. In particular, we consider the following stochastic learning problem

min𝐱⁡f​(𝐱)≔min𝐱⁡1n​∑i=1nfi​(𝐱),≔subscript𝐱𝑓𝐱subscript𝐱1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}f({\mathbf{x}})\coloneqq\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}),\vspace{-1mm} (1)

where the local objective function of each node i𝑖i is defined as the expected loss of its local sample distributions

fi​(𝐱)≔𝔼ξ∼𝒫i​[ℓ​(𝐱,ξ)].≔subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉superscript𝒫𝑖delimited-[]ℓ𝐱𝜉f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim{\mathcal{P}}^{i}}\,[\ell(\mathbf{x},\xi)].\vspace{-1mm} (2)

Here ℓ:ℝp×ℝu→ℝ:ℓsuperscriptℝ𝑝superscriptℝ𝑢→ℝ\ell\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{R}^{p}\times\mathbb{R}^{u}\to\mathbb{R} is a stochastic loss function, 𝐱∈ℝp𝐱superscriptℝ𝑝{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{p} is the model vector, and ξ∈ℝu𝜉superscriptℝ𝑢\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{u} is a random variable with unknown probability distribution 𝒫isuperscript𝒫𝑖{\mathcal{P}}^{i}. Moreover, f:ℝp→ℝ:𝑓superscriptℝ𝑝→ℝf\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{R}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} denotes the expected loss function also called population risk. In our considered federated setting, each of the n𝑛n distributed nodes generates a local loss function according to a distribution 𝒫isuperscript𝒫𝑖{\mathcal{P}}^{i} resulting in a local stochastic function fi​(𝐱)≔𝔼ξ∼𝒫i​[ℓ​(𝐱,ξ)]≔subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉superscript𝒫𝑖delimited-[]ℓ𝐱𝜉f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim{\mathcal{P}}^{i}}\,[\ell(\mathbf{x},\xi)]. A special case of this formulation is when each node i𝑖i maintains a collection of m𝑚m samples from distribution 𝒫isuperscript𝒫𝑖{\mathcal{P}}^{i} which we denote by 𝒟i={ξ1i,⋯,ξmi}superscript𝒟𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑖1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑖𝑚{\mathcal{D}}^{i}=\{\xi^{i}_{1},\cdots,\xi^{i}_{m}\} for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. This results in the following empirical risk minimization problem over the collection of n​m𝑛𝑚nm samples in 𝒟≔𝒟1∪⋯∪𝒟n≔𝒟superscript𝒟1⋯superscript𝒟𝑛{\mathcal{D}}\coloneqq{\mathcal{D}}^{1}\cup\cdots\cup{\mathcal{D}}^{n}:

min𝐱⁡L​(𝐱)=min𝐱⁡1n​m​∑ξ∈𝒟ℓ​(𝐱,ξ),subscript𝐱𝐿𝐱subscript𝐱1𝑛𝑚subscript𝜉𝒟ℓ𝐱𝜉\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}L({\mathbf{x}})=\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}\frac{1}{nm}\sum_{\xi\in{\mathcal{D}}}\ell({\mathbf{x}},\xi),\vspace{-1mm} (3)

We denote the optimal model 𝐱∗superscript𝐱{\mathbf{x}}^{*} as the solution to the expected risk minimization problem in (1) and denote the minimum loss f∗≔min𝐱⁡f​(𝐱)=f​(𝐱∗)≔superscript𝑓subscript𝐱𝑓𝐱𝑓superscript𝐱f^{*}\coloneqq\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}f({\mathbf{x}})=f({\mathbf{x}}^{*}) as the optimal objective function value of the expected risk minimization problem in (1). In this work, we focus on the case that the data over the n𝑛n nodes is independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), which implies the local distributions are common.

As stated above, our goal is to minimize the expected loss f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}). However, due to the fact that we do not have access to the underlying distribution 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}}, there have been prior works that focus on minimizing the empirical risk L​(𝐱)𝐿𝐱L(\mathbf{x}) which can be viewed as an approximation of the expected loss f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}). The accuracy of this approximation is determined by the number of samples N=n​m𝑁𝑛𝑚N=nm. It has been shown that for convex losses ℓℓ\ell, the population risk f𝑓f is at most 𝒪​(1/n​m)𝒪1𝑛𝑚{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}) distant from the empirical risk L𝐿L, uniformly and with high probability (Bottou and Bousquet, 2008). That is, sup𝐱|f​(𝐱)−L​(𝐱)|≤𝒪​(1/n​m)subscriptsupremum𝐱𝑓𝐱𝐿𝐱𝒪1𝑛𝑚\sup_{\mathbf{x}}|f(\mathbf{x})-L(\mathbf{x})|\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}) with high probability. This result implies that if each of the n𝑛n nodes separately minimizes its local empirical loss function, the expected deviation from the local solution and the solution to the population risk minimization problem is of 𝒪​(1/m)𝒪1𝑚{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{m}) (note that each node has access to m𝑚m data samples). However, if the nodes manage to somehow share or synchronize their solutions, then a more accurate solution can be achieved, that is a solution with accuracy of order 𝒪​(1/n​m)𝒪1𝑛𝑚{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}). Therefore, when all the m​n𝑚𝑛mn available samples are leveraged, one can obtain a solution 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} that satisfies 𝔼​[L​(𝐱^)−L​(𝐱∗)]≤𝒪​(1/n​m)𝔼delimited-[]𝐿^𝐱𝐿superscript𝐱𝒪1𝑛𝑚\mathbb{E}[L(\hat{\mathbf{x}})-L(\mathbf{x}^{*})]\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}). This also implies that 𝔼​[f​(𝐱^)−min𝐱⁡f​(𝐱)]≤𝒪​(1/n​m)𝔼delimited-[]𝑓^𝐱subscript𝐱𝑓𝐱𝒪1𝑛𝑚\mathbb{E}[f(\hat{\mathbf{x}})-\min_{\mathbf{x}}f(\mathbf{x})]\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}).

For the case of non-convex loss function ℓℓ\ell, however, finding the solution to the expected risk minimization problem in (1) is hard. Even further, finding (or testing) a local optimum is NP-hard in many cases (Murty and Kabadi, 1987). Therefore, for non-convex losses we relax our main goal and instead look for first-order optimal solutions (or stationary points) for (1). That is, we aim to find a model 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} that satisfies ∥∇f​(𝐱^)∥≤ϵdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓^𝐱italic-ϵ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\hat{\mathbf{x}})\right\rVert}\leq\epsilon for an arbitrarily small approximation error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Mei et al. (2018) characterized the gap for the gradients of the two expected risk and empirical risk functions. That is, if the gradient of loss is sub-Gaussian, then with high probability sup𝐱∥∇L​(𝐱)−∇f​(𝐱)∥≤𝒪​(1/n​m)subscriptsupremum𝐱delimited-∥∥∇𝐿𝐱∇𝑓𝐱𝒪1𝑛𝑚\sup_{\mathbf{x}}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla L(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert}\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}). This result further implies that having all the nodes contribute in minimizing the empirical risk results in better approximation for a first-order stationary point of the expected risk L𝐿L. In summary, our goal in non-convex setting is to find 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} that satisfies ∥∇f​(𝐱)∥≤𝒪​(1/n​m)delimited-∥∥∇𝑓𝐱𝒪1𝑛𝑚\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert}\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}) which also implies ∥∇L​(𝐱)∥≤𝒪​(1/n​m)delimited-∥∥∇𝐿𝐱𝒪1𝑛𝑚\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla L(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert}\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}).

3 Proposed FedPAQ Method

In this section, we present our proposed communication-efficient federated learning method called FedPAQ, which consists of three main modules: (1) periodic averaging, (2) partial node participation, and (3) quantized message passing.

3.1 Periodic averaging

As explained in Section 2, to leverage from all the available data samples on the nodes, any training method should incorporate synchronizing the intermediate models obtained at local devices. One approach is to let the participating nodes synchronize their models through the parameter server in each iteration of the training. This, however, implies many rounds of communication between the federated nodes and the parameter server which results in communication contention over the network. Instead, we let the participating nodes conduct a number of local updates and synchronize through the parameter server periodically. To be more specific, once nodes pull an updated model from the server, they update the model locally by running τ𝜏\tau iterations of the SGD method and then send proper information to the server for updating the aggregate model. Indeed, this periodic averaging scheme reduces the rounds of communication between server and the nodes and consequently the overall communication cost of training the model. In particular, for the case that we plan to run T𝑇T iterations of SGD at each node, nodes need to communicate with the server K=T/τ𝐾𝑇𝜏K=T/\tau rounds, hence reducing the total communication cost by a factor of 1/τ1𝜏1/\tau.

Choosing a larger value of τ𝜏\tau indeed reduces the rounds of communication for a fixed number of iterations T𝑇T. However, if our goal is to obtain a specific accuracy ε𝜀\varepsilon, choosing a very large value for τ𝜏\tau is not necessarily optimal as by increasing τ𝜏\tau the noise of the system increases and the local models approach the local optimal solutions instead of the global optimal solution. Hence, we might end up running more iterations T𝑇T to achieve a specific accuracy ε𝜀\varepsilon comparing to a case that τ𝜏\tau is small. Indeed, a crucial question that we need to address is finding the optimal choice of τ𝜏\tau for minimizing the overall communication cost of the process.

3.2 Partial node participation

In a federated network, often there is a large number of devices such as smart phones communicating through a base station. On one hand, base stations have limited download bandwidth and hence only a few of devices are able to simultaneously upload their messages to the base station. Due to this limitation the messages sent from the devices will be pipelined at the base station which results in a dramatically slow training. On the other hand, having all of the devices participate through the whole training process induces a large communication overhead on the network which is often costly. Moreover, in practice not all the devices contribute in each round of the training. Indeed, there are multiple factors that determine whether a device can participate in the training (McMahan and Ramage, 2017): a device should be available in the reachable range of the base station; a device should be idle, plugged in and connected to a free wireless network during the training; etc.

Our proposed FedPAQ method captures the restrictions mentioned above. In particular, we assume that among the total of n𝑛n devices, only r𝑟r nodes (r≤n𝑟𝑛r\leq n) are available in each round of the training. We can also assume that due to the availability criterion described before, such available devices are randomly and uniformly distributed over the network (Sahu et al., 2018). In summary, in each period k=0,1,⋯,K−1𝑘01⋯𝐾1k=0,1,\cdots,K-1 of the training algorithm, the parameter server sends its current model 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} to all the r𝑟r nodes in subset 𝒮ksubscript𝒮𝑘{\mathcal{S}}_{k}, which are distributed uniformly at random among the total n𝑛n nodes, i.e., Pr​[𝒮k]=1/(nr)Prdelimited-[]subscript𝒮𝑘1binomial𝑛𝑟\text{Pr}\left[{\mathcal{S}}_{k}\right]=1/{n\choose r}.

3.3 Quantized message-passing

Another aspect of the communication bottleneck in federated learning is the limited uplink bandwidth at the devices which makes the communication from devices to the parameter server slow and expensive. Hence, it is critical to reduce the size of the uploaded messages from the federated devices (Li et al., 2019a). Our proposal is to employ quantization operators on the transmitted massages. Depending on the accuracy of the quantizer, the network communication overhead is reduced by exchanging the quantized updates.

In the proposed FedPAQ, each node i∈𝒮k𝑖subscript𝒮𝑘i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k} obtains the model 𝐱k,τ(i)subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau} after running τ𝜏\tau local iterations of an optimization method (possibly SGD) on the most recent model 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} that it has received form the server. Then each node i𝑖i applies a quantizer operator Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) on the difference between the received model and its updated model, i.e., 𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱ksubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}, and uploads the quantized vector Q​(𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱k)𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘Q(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}) to the parameter server. Once these quantized vectors are sent to the server, it decodes the quantized signals and combines them to come up with a new model 𝐱k+1subscript𝐱𝑘1{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}.

Next, we describe a widely-used random quantizer.

Example 1 (Low-precision quantizer (Alistarh et al., 2017)).

For any variable 𝐱∈ℝp𝐱superscriptℝ𝑝\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}, the low precision quantizer QLP:ℝp→ℝp:superscript𝑄LPsuperscriptℝ𝑝→superscriptℝ𝑝Q^{\text{LP}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{R}^{p}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p} is defined as below

where ξi​(𝐱,s)subscript𝜉𝑖𝐱𝑠\xi_{i}(\mathbf{x},s) is a random variable taking on value l+1/s𝑙1𝑠\nicefrac{{l+1}}{{s}} with probability |xi|∥𝐱∥​s−lsubscript𝑥𝑖delimited-∥∥𝐱𝑠𝑙\frac{|x_{i}|}{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}}s-l and l/s𝑙𝑠\nicefrac{{l}}{{s}} otherwise. 3.4 Algorithm update

Now we use the building blocks developed in Sections 3.1-3.3 to precisely present FedPAQ. Our proposed method consists of K𝐾K periods, and during a period, each node performs τ𝜏\tau local updates, which results in total number of T=K​τ𝑇𝐾𝜏T=K\tau iterations. In each period k=0,⋯,K−1𝑘0⋯𝐾1k=0,\cdots,K-1 of the algorithm, the parameter server picks r≤n𝑟𝑛r\leq n nodes uniformly at random which we denote by 𝒮ksubscript𝒮𝑘{\mathcal{S}}_{k}. The parameter server then broadcasts its current model 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} to all the nodes in 𝒮ksubscript𝒮𝑘{\mathcal{S}}_{k} and each node i∈𝒮k𝑖subscript𝒮𝑘i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k} performs τ𝜏\tau local SGD updates using its local dataset. To be more specific, let 𝐱k,t(i)subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝑡\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t} denote the model at node i𝑖i at t𝑡t-th iteration of the k𝑘k-th period. At each local iteration t=0,⋯,τ−1𝑡0⋯𝜏1t=0,\cdots,\tau-1, node i𝑖i updates its local model according to the following rule:

𝐱k,t+1(i)=𝐱k,t(i)−ηk,t​∇~​fi​(𝐱k,t(i)),subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑘𝑡~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝑡\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t+1}=\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}-\eta_{k,t}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}\right),\vspace{-1mm} (5)

where the stochastic gradient ∇~​fi~∇subscript𝑓𝑖\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i} is computed using a random sample111The method can be easily made compatible with using a mini-batch during each iteration. picked from the local dataset 𝒟isuperscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}^{i}. Note that all the nodes begin with a common initialization 𝐱k,0(i)=𝐱ksubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘0subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k}. After τ𝜏\tau local updates, each node computes the overall update in that period, that is 𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱ksubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}, and uploads a quantized update Q​(𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱k)𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘Q(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}) to the parameter server.

The parameter server then aggregates the r𝑟r received quantized local updates and computes the next model according to

𝐱k+1=𝐱k+1r​∑i∈𝒮kQ​(𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱k),subscript𝐱𝑘1subscript𝐱𝑘1𝑟subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑘𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k+1}=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{r}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right),\vspace{-1mm} (6)

and the procedure is repeated for K𝐾K periods. The proposed method is formally summarized in Algorithm 1.

4 Convergence Analysis

In this section, we present our theoretical results on the guarantees of the FedPAQ method. We first consider the strongly convex setting and state the convergence guarantee of FedPAQ for such losses in Theorem 1. Then, in Theorem 2, we present the overall complexity of our method for finding a first-order stationary point of the aggregate objective function f𝑓f, when the loss function ℓℓ\ell is non-convex (All proofs are provided in the supplementary material). Before that, we first mention three customary assumptions required for both convex and non-convex settings.

Assumption 1.

The random quantizer Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) is unbiased and its variance grows with the squared of l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of its argument, i.e.,

𝔼​[Q​(𝐱)|𝐱]=𝐱,𝔼​[∥Q​(𝐱)−𝐱∥2|𝐱]≤q​∥𝐱∥2,formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑄𝐱𝐱𝐱𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑄𝐱𝐱2𝐱𝑞superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐱2\mathbb{E}\left[Q(\mathbf{x})|\mathbf{x}\right]=\mathbf{x},\quad\mathbb{E}\left[\mathinner{\!\left\lVert Q(\mathbf{x})-\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}^{2}|\mathbf{x}\right]\leq q\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}^{2},\vspace{-1mm} (7)

for some positive real constant q𝑞q and any 𝐱∈ℝp𝐱superscriptℝ𝑝\mathbf{x}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}.

Assumption 2.

The loss functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are L𝐿L-smooth with respect to 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, i.e., for any 𝐱,𝐱^∈ℝp𝐱^𝐱superscriptℝ𝑝\mathbf{x},{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}, we have ∥∇fi​(𝐱)−∇fi​(𝐱^)∥≤L​∥𝐱−𝐱^∥delimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝑓𝑖^𝐱𝐿delimited-∥∥𝐱^𝐱\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f_{i}({\hat{\mathbf{x}}})\right\rVert}\leq L\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\right\rVert}.

Assumption 3.

Stochastic gradients ∇~​fi​(𝐱)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}) are unbiased and variance bounded, i.e., 𝔼ξ​[∇~​fi​(𝐱)]=∇fi​(𝐱)subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]~∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x})]=\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}) and 𝔼ξ​[‖∇~​fi​(𝐱)−∇fi​(𝐱)‖2]≤σ2.subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]superscriptnorm~∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[\|\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}.

The conditions in Assumption 1 ensure that output of quantization is an unbiased estimator of the input with a variance that is proportional to the norm-squared of the input. This condition is satisfied with most common quantization schemes including the low-precision quantizer introduced in Example 1. Assumption 2 implies that the gradients of local functions ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} and the aggregated objective function ∇f∇𝑓\nabla f are also L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous. The conditions in Assumption 3 on the bias and variance of stochastic gradients are also customary. Note that this is a much weaker assumption compared to the one that uniformly bounds the expected norm of the stochastic gradient.

Challenges in analyzing the FedPAQ method. Here, we highlight the main theoretical challenges in proving our main results. As outlined in the description of the proposed method, in the k𝑘k-th round of FedPAQ, each participating node i𝑖i updates its local model for τ𝜏\tau iterations via SGD method in (5). Let us focus on a case that we use a constant stepsize for the purpose of this discussion. First consider the naive parallel SGD case which corresponds to τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. The updated local model after τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 local update is

𝐱k,τ(i)=𝐱k,0(i)−η​∇~​fi​(𝐱k,0(i)).subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘0𝜂~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘0\displaystyle\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}=\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}-\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}\right). (8)

Note that 𝐱k,0(i)=𝐱ksubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘0subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k} is the parameter server’s model sent to the nodes. Since we assume the stochastic gradients are unbiased estimators of the gradient, it yields that the local update 𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱ksubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k} is an unbiased estimator of −η​∇f​(𝐱k)𝜂∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k}) for every participating node. Hence, the aggregated updates at the server and the updated model 𝐱k+1subscript𝐱𝑘1\mathbf{x}_{k+1} can be simply related to the current model 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} as one step of parallel SGD. However, this is not the case when the period length τ𝜏\tau is larger than 111. For instance, in the case that τ=2𝜏2\tau=2, the local updated model after τ=2𝜏2\tau=2 iterations is

𝐱k,τ(i)=𝐱k−η​∇~​fi​(𝐱k)−η​∇~​fi​(𝐱k−η​∇~​fi​(𝐱k)).subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘𝜂~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘𝜂~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘𝜂~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}\!=\!\mathbf{x}_{k}\!-\!\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)\!-\!\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\!-\!\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)\right). (9)

Clearly, 𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱ksubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k} is not an unbiased estimator of −η​∇f​(𝐱k)𝜂∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k}) or −η​∇f​(𝐱k−η​∇f​(𝐱k))𝜂∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝜂∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k})). This demonstrates that the aggregated model at server cannot be treated as τ𝜏\tau iterations of parallel SGD, since each local update contains a bias. Indeed, this bias gets propagated when τ𝜏\tau gets larger. For our running example τ=2𝜏2\tau=2, the variance of the bias, i.e. 𝔼​‖η​∇~​fi​(𝐱k−η​∇~​fi​(𝐱k))‖2𝔼superscriptnorm𝜂~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘𝜂~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘2\mathbb{E}\|\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{k}))\|^{2} is not uniformly bounded either (Assumption 3), which makes the analysis even more challenging compared to the works with bounded gradient assumption (e.g. (Stich, 2018; Yu et al., 2019)).

4.1 Strongly convex setting

Now we proceed to establish the convergence rate of the proposed FedPAQ method for a federated setting with strongly convex and smooth loss function ℓℓ\ell. We first formally state the strong convexity assumption.

Assumption 4.

The loss functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, i.e., for any 𝐱,𝐱^∈ℝp𝐱^𝐱superscriptℝ𝑝\mathbf{x},{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p} we have that ⟨∇fi​(𝐱)−∇fi​(𝐱^),𝐱−𝐱^⟩≥μ​∥𝐱−𝐱^∥2.∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝑓𝑖^𝐱𝐱^𝐱𝜇superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐱^𝐱2\langle\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f_{i}({\hat{\mathbf{x}}}),\mathbf{x}-{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\rangle\geq\mu\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\right\rVert}^{2}.

Theorem 1 (Strongly convex loss).

Consider the sequence of iterates 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} at the parameter server generated according to the FedPAQ method outlined in Algorithm 1. Suppose the conditions in Assumptions 1–4 are satisfied. Further, let us define the constant B1subscript𝐵1B_{1} as

where q𝑞q is the quantization variance parameter defined in (7) and r𝑟r is the number of active nodes at each round of communication. If we set the stepsize in FedPAQ as ηk,t=ηk=4​μ−1/k​τ+1subscript𝜂𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑘4superscript𝜇1𝑘𝜏1\eta_{k,t}=\eta_{k}=\nicefrac{{4\mu^{-1}}}{{k\tau+1}}, then for any k≥k0𝑘subscript𝑘0k\geq k_{0} where k0subscript𝑘0k_{0} is the smallest integer satisfying

Remark 1.

Under the same conditions as in Theorem 1 and for a total number of iterations T=K​τ≥k0​τ𝑇𝐾𝜏subscript𝑘0𝜏T=K\tau\geq k_{0}\tau we have the following convergence rate

𝔼​‖𝐱K−𝐱∗‖2≤𝒪​(τT)+𝒪​(τ2T2)𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝐾superscript𝐱2𝒪𝜏𝑇𝒪superscript𝜏2superscript𝑇2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{x}_{K}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\|^{2}\leq{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{\tau}{T}\bigg{)}+{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{\tau^{2}}{T^{2}}\bigg{)} (16)
+𝒪​((τ−1)2T)+𝒪​(τ−1T2).𝒪superscript𝜏12𝑇𝒪𝜏1superscript𝑇2\displaystyle\quad+{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{(\tau-1)^{2}}{T}\bigg{)}+{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{\tau-1}{T^{2}}\bigg{)}. (17)

As expected, the fastest convergence rate is attained when the contributing nodes synchronize with the parameter server in each iteration, i.e. when τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. Theorem 1 however characterizes how large the period length τ𝜏\tau can be picked. In particular, any pick of τ=o​(T)𝜏𝑜𝑇\tau=o(\sqrt{T}) ensures the convergence of the FedPAQ to the global optimal for strongly convex losses.

Remark 2.

By setting τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, q=0𝑞0q=0 and r=n𝑟𝑛r=n, Theorem 1 recovers the convergence rate of vanilla parallel SGD, i.e., 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(1/T) for strongly-convex losses. Our result is however more general since we remove the uniformly bounded assumption on the norm of stochastic gradient. For τ≥1𝜏1\tau\geq 1, Theorem 1 does not recover the result in (Stich, 2018) due to our weaker condition in Assumption 3. Nevertheless, the same rate 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(1/T) is guaranteed by FedPAQ for constant values of τ𝜏\tau.

4.2 Non-convex setting

We now present the convergence result of FedPAQ for smooth non-convex loss functions.

Theorem 2 (Non-convex Losses).

Consider the sequence of iterates 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k} at the parameter server generated according to the FedPAQ method outlined in Algorithm 1. Suppose the conditions in Assumptions 1–3 are satisfied. Further, let us define the constant B2subscript𝐵2B_{2} as

B2≔qn+4​(n−r)r​(n−1)​(1+q),≔subscript𝐵2𝑞𝑛4𝑛𝑟𝑟𝑛11𝑞B_{2}\coloneqq\frac{q}{n}+\frac{4(n-r)}{r(n-1)}(1+q),\vspace{-1mm} (18)

where q𝑞q is the quantization variance parameter defined in (7) and r𝑟r is the number of active nodes at each round. If the total number of iterations T𝑇T and the period length τ𝜏\tau satisfy the following conditions,

T≥2,τ≤B22+0.8−B28​T,formulae-sequence𝑇2𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐵220.8subscript𝐵28𝑇T\geq 2,\qquad\tau\leq\frac{\sqrt{B_{2}^{2}+0.8}-B_{2}}{8}\sqrt{T},\vspace{-1mm} (19)

and we set the stepsize as ηk,t=1/L​Tsubscript𝜂𝑘𝑡1𝐿𝑇\eta_{k,t}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{L\sqrt{T}}}, then the following first-order stationary condition holds

1T​∑k=0K−1∑t=0τ−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝐱¯k,t)∥21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript¯𝐱𝑘𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,t})\right\rVert}^{2} (20)
≤2​L​(f​(𝐱0)−f∗)T+N1​1T+N2​τ−1T,absent2𝐿𝑓subscript𝐱0superscript𝑓𝑇subscript𝑁11𝑇subscript𝑁2𝜏1𝑇\displaystyle\quad\leq\frac{2L(f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{*})}{\sqrt{T}}+N_{1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}+N_{2}\frac{\tau-1}{T}, (21)

where the constants in (21) are defined as

N1≔(1+q)​σ2n​(1+n​(n−r)r​(n−1)),N2≔σ2n​(n+1).formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑁11𝑞superscript𝜎2𝑛1𝑛𝑛𝑟𝑟𝑛1≔subscript𝑁2superscript𝜎2𝑛𝑛1\displaystyle N_{1}\coloneqq(1+q)\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\left(1+\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right),\quad\!\!N_{2}\coloneqq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}(n+1).
Remark 3.

The result in Theorem 2 implies the following order-wise rate

1T​∑k=0K−1∑t=0τ−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝐱¯k,t)∥2≤𝒪​(1T)+𝒪​(τ−1T).1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript¯𝐱𝑘𝑡2𝒪1𝑇𝒪𝜏1𝑇\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,t})\right\rVert}^{2}\leq{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\tau\!-\!1}{T}\right).

Clearly, the fastest convergence rate is achieved for the smallest possible period length, i.e., τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. This however implies that the edge nodes communicate with the parameter server in each iteration, i.e. T𝑇T rounds of communications which is costly. On the other hand, the conditions (19) in Theorem 2 allow the period length τ𝜏\tau to grow up to 𝒪​(T)𝒪𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{T}) which results in an overall convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{T}) in reaching an stationary point. This result shows that with only 𝒪​(T)𝒪𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{T}) rounds of communication FedPAQ can still ensure the convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex losses.

Remark 4.

Theorem 2 recovers the convergence rate of the vanilla parallel SGD (Yu et al., 2019) for non-convex losses as a special case of τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, q=0𝑞0q=0 and r=n𝑟𝑛r=n. Nevertheless, we remove the uniformly bounded assumption on the norm of the stochastic gradient in our theoretical analysis. We also recover the result in (Wang and Joshi, 2018) when there is no quatization q=0𝑞0q=0 and we have a full device participation r=n𝑟𝑛r=n.

It is worth mentioning that for Theorems 1 and 2, one can use a batch of size m𝑚m for each local SGD update and the same results hold by changing σ2/nsuperscript𝜎2𝑛\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{n}} to σ2/m​nsuperscript𝜎2𝑚𝑛\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{mn}}.

5 Numerical Results and Discussions

The proposed FedPAQ method reduces the communication load by employing three modules: periodic averaging, partial node participation, and quantization. This communication reduction however comes with a cost in reducing the convergence accuracy and hence requiring more iterations of the training, which we characterized in Theorems 1 and 2. In this section, we empirically study this communication-computation trade-off and evaluate FedPAQ in comparison to other benchmarks. To evaluate the total cost of a method, we first need to specifically model such cost. We consider the total training time as the cost objective which consists of communication and computation time (Berahas et al., 2018; Reisizadeh et al., 2019c). Consider T𝑇T iterations of training with FedPAQ that consists of K=T/τ𝐾𝑇𝜏K=T/\tau rounds of communication. In each round, r𝑟r workers compute τ𝜏\tau iterations of SGD with batchsize B𝐵B and send a quantized vector of size p𝑝p to the server.

Communication time. We fix a bandwidth BW and define the communication time in each round as the total number of uploaded bits divided by BW. Total number of bits in each round is r⋅|Q​(p,s)|⋅𝑟𝑄𝑝𝑠r\cdot|Q(p,s)|, where |Q​(p,s)|𝑄𝑝𝑠|Q(p,s)| denotes the number of bits required to encode a quantized vector of dimension p𝑝p according to a specific quantizer with s𝑠s levels. In our simulations, we use the low-precision quantizer described in Example 1 and assume it takes p​F𝑝𝐹pF bits to represent an unquantized vector of length p𝑝p, where F𝐹F is typically 323232 bits.

Computation time. We consider the well-known shifted-exponential model for gradient computation time (Lee et al., 2017). In particular, we assume that for any node, computing the gradients in a period with τ𝜏\tau iterations and using batchsize B𝐵B takes a deterministic shift τ⋅B⋅shift⋅𝜏𝐵shift\tau\cdot B\cdot\texttt{shift} plus a random exponential time with mean value τ⋅B⋅scale−1⋅𝜏𝐵superscriptscale1\tau\cdot B\cdot\texttt{scale}^{-1}, where shift and scale are respectively shift and scale parameters of the shifted-exponential distribution. Total computation time of each round is then the largest local computation time among the r𝑟r contributing nodes. We also define a communication-computation ratio

CcommCcomp=p​F/BWshift+1/scalesubscript𝐶commsubscript𝐶comp𝑝𝐹BWshift1scale\displaystyle\frac{C_{\texttt{comm}}}{C_{\texttt{comp}}}=\frac{pF/\texttt{BW}}{\texttt{shift}+1/\texttt{scale}}

as the communication time for a length-p𝑝p-vector over the average computation time for one gradient vector. This ratio captures the relative cost of communication and computation, and since communication is a major bottleneck, we have Ccomm/Ccomp≫1much-greater-thansubscript𝐶commsubscript𝐶comp1{C_{\texttt{comm}}}/{C_{\texttt{comp}}}\gg 1. In all of our experiments, we use batchsize B=10𝐵10B=10 and finely tune the stepsize’s coefficient.

5.1 Logistic Regression on MNIST

In Figure 1, the top four plots demonstrate the training time for a regularized logistic regression problem over MNIST dataset (‘0’ and ‘8’ digits) for T=100𝑇100T=100 iterations. The network has n=50𝑛50n=50 nodes each loaded with 200200200 samples. We set Ccomm/Ccomp=100/1subscript𝐶commsubscript𝐶comp1001C_{\texttt{comm}}/C_{\texttt{comp}}=100/1 to capture the communication bottleneck. Among the three parameters quantization levels s𝑠s, number of active nodes in each round r𝑟r, and period length τ𝜏\tau, we fix two and vary the third one. First plot demonstrates the relative training loss for different quantization levels s∈{1,5,10}𝑠1510s\in\{1,5,10\} and the case with no quantization which corresponds to the FedAvg method (McMahan et al., 2016). The other two parameters are fixed to (τ,r)=(5,25)𝜏𝑟525(\tau,r)=(5,25). Each curve shows the training time versus the achieved training loss for the aggregated model at the server for each round k=1,⋯,T/τ𝑘1⋯𝑇𝜏k=1,\cdots,T/\tau. In the second plot, (s,τ)=(1,5)𝑠𝜏15(s,\tau)=(1,5) are fixed. The third plot demonstrates the effect of period length τ𝜏\tau in the communication-computation tradeoff. As demonstrated, after T/τ𝑇𝜏T/\tau rounds, smaller choices for τ𝜏\tau (e.g. τ=1,2𝜏12\tau=1,2) result in slower convergence while the larger ones (e.g. τ=50𝜏50\tau=50) run faster though providing less accurate models. Here τ=10𝜏10\tau=10 is the optimal choice. The last plot compares the training time of FedPAQ with two other benchmarks FedAvg and QSGD. For both FedPAQ and FedAvg, we set τ=2𝜏2\tau=2 while FedPAQ and QSGD use quantization with s=1𝑠1s=1 level. All three methods use r=n=50𝑟𝑛50r=n=50 nodes in each round.

5.2 Neural Network training over CIFAR-10

We conduct another set of numerical experiments to evaluate the performance of FedPAQ on non-convex and smooth objectives. Here we train a neural network with four hidden layers consisting of n=50𝑛50n=50 nodes and more thatn 929292K parameters, where we use 101010K samples from CIFAR-10 dataset with 101010 labels. Since models are much larger than the previous setup, we increase the communication-computation ratio to Ccomm/Ccomp=1000/1subscript𝐶commsubscript𝐶comp10001C_{\texttt{comm}}/C_{\texttt{comp}}=1000/1 to better capture the communication bottleneck for large models. The bottom four plots in Figure 1 demonstrate the training loss over time for T=100𝑇100T=100 iterations. In the first plot, (τ,r)=(2,25)𝜏𝑟225(\tau,r)=(2,25) are fixed and we vary the quantization levels. The second plot shows the effect of r𝑟r while (s,τ)=(1,2)𝑠𝜏12(s,\tau)=(1,2). The communication-computation tradeoff in terms of period length τ𝜏\tau is demonstrated in the third plot, where picking τ=10𝜏10\tau=10 turns out to attain the fastest convergence. Lastly, we compare FedPAQ with other benchmarks in the forth plot. Here, we set (s,r,τ)=(1,20,10)𝑠𝑟𝜏12010(s,r,\tau)=(1,20,10) in FedPAQ, (r,τ)=(20,10)𝑟𝜏2010(r,\tau)=(20,10) in FedAvg and (s,r,τ)=(1,50,1)𝑠𝑟𝜏1501(s,r,\tau)=(1,50,1) for QSGD.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we addressed some of the communication and scalability challenges of federated learning and proposed FedPAQ, a communication-efficient federated learning method with provable performance guarantees. FedPAQ is based on three modules: (1) periodic averaging in which each edge node performs local iterative updates; (2) partial node participation which captures the random availability of the edge nodes; and (3) quantization in which each model is quantized before being uploaded to the server. We provided rigorous analysis for our proposed method for two general classes of strongly-convex and non-convex losses. We further provided numerical results evaluating the performance of FedPAQ, and discussing the trade-off between communication and computation.

Proof.

7.2 Proof of Lemma 2

According to update rule in Algorithm 1, local model at node i𝑖i for each iteration t=0,⋯,τ−1𝑡0⋯𝜏1t=0,\cdots,\tau-1 of period k=0,⋯,K−1𝑘0⋯𝐾1k=0,\cdots,K-1 can be written as follows:

7.3 Proof of Lemma 3

According to the notations defined on (24), we can write

8.1 Discussion on stepsize η𝜂\eta

Here, we consider the constraint on the stepsize derived in (175) and show that if η𝜂\eta is picked according to Theorem 2, then it also satisfies (175). First, let the stepsize satisfy 1−L​η≥0.11𝐿𝜂0.11-L\eta\geq 0.1. Now, if the following holds

L​(1n​q+4​n−rr​(n−1)​(1+q))​τ​η+2​L2​(τ​η)2≤0.1,𝐿1𝑛𝑞4𝑛𝑟𝑟𝑛11𝑞𝜏𝜂2superscript𝐿2superscript𝜏𝜂20.1\displaystyle L\left(\frac{1}{n}q+4\frac{n-r}{r(n-1)}(1+q)\right)\tau\eta+2L^{2}(\tau\eta)^{2}\leq 0.1, (184)

the condition in (175) also holds. It is straightforward to see when (184) holds. To do so, consider the following quadratic inequality in terms of y=η​τ𝑦𝜂𝜏y=\eta\tau:

2​L2​y2+L​B2​y−0.1≤0,2superscript𝐿2superscript𝑦2𝐿subscript𝐵2𝑦0.10\displaystyle 2L^{2}y^{2}+LB_{2}y-0.1\leq 0, (185)

where

B2≔1n​q+4​n−rr​(n−1)​(1+q).≔subscript𝐵21𝑛𝑞4𝑛𝑟𝑟𝑛11𝑞\displaystyle B_{2}\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}q+4\frac{n-r}{r(n-1)}(1+q). (186)

We can solve the quadratic form in (185) for y=η​τ𝑦𝜂𝜏y=\eta\tau which yields

η​τ≤B22+0.8−B24​L.𝜂𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐵220.8subscript𝐵24𝐿\displaystyle\eta\tau\leq\frac{\sqrt{B_{2}^{2}+0.8}-B_{2}}{4L}. (187)

This implies that if the parameter τ𝜏\tau and the stepsize η𝜂\eta satisfy (187) and η≤0.9/L𝜂0.9𝐿\eta\leq\nicefrac{{0.9}}{{L}}, then the condition (175) is satisfied. In particular, for our pick of η=1/L​T𝜂1𝐿𝑇\eta=\nicefrac{{1}}{{L\sqrt{T}}}, the condition η≤0.9/L𝜂0.9𝐿\eta\leq\nicefrac{{0.9}}{{L}} holds if T≥2𝑇2T\geq 2; and the constraint in (187) is equivalent to having

τ𝜏\displaystyle\tau ≤B22+0.8−B28​T.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐵220.8subscript𝐵28𝑇\displaystyle\leq\frac{\sqrt{B_{2}^{2}+0.8}-B_{2}}{8}\sqrt{T}. (188)

8.2 Proof of Lemma 6

8.4 Proof of Lemma 8

According to definitions in (24) and using Assumption 1 we have

𝔼​∥𝐱^k+1−𝐱¯k,τ∥2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript^𝐱𝑘1subscript¯𝐱𝑘𝜏2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}\right\rVert}^{2} ≤1n2​∑i∈[n]q​𝔼​∥𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱k∥2.absent1superscript𝑛2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑞𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum_{i\in[n]}q\,\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2}. (226)

Using the model update in (200) and Assumption 3, we can write

=η2​𝔼​∥∇~​fi​(𝐱k)−∇f​(𝐱k)+⋯+∇~​fi​(𝐱k,τ−1(i))−∇f​(𝐱k,τ−1(i))∥2absentsuperscript𝜂2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐱𝑘∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘⋯~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏1∇𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏12\displaystyle=\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{k})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k})+\cdots+\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left({\mathbf{x}}^{(i)}_{k,\tau-1}\right)-\nabla f\left({\mathbf{x}}^{(i)}_{k,\tau-1}\right)\right\rVert}^{2} (228)

𝔼​∥𝐱^k+1−𝐱¯k,τ∥2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript^𝐱𝑘1subscript¯𝐱𝑘𝜏2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}\right\rVert}^{2} ≤q​σ2n​τ​η2+q​1n2​τ​η2​∑i∈[n]∑t=0τ−1∥∇f​(𝐱k,t(i))∥2,absent𝑞superscript𝜎2𝑛𝜏superscript𝜂2𝑞1superscript𝑛2𝜏superscript𝜂2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝑡2\displaystyle\leq q\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\tau\eta^{2}+q\frac{1}{n^{2}}\tau\eta^{2}\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f\left({\mathbf{x}}^{(i)}_{k,t}\right)\right\rVert}^{2}, (231)

as desired in Lemma 8.

8.5 Proof of Lemma 9

The steps to prove the bound in (142) for strongly convex losses in Lemma 4 can also be applied for non-convex losses. That is, we can use (142) and together with (230) conclude the following:

𝔼​∥𝐱^k+1−𝐱k+1∥2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript^𝐱𝑘1subscript𝐱𝑘12\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{x}_{k+1}\right\rVert}^{2} ≤1r​(n−1)​(1−rn)​4​(1+q)​∑i∈[n]∥𝐱k,τ(i)−𝐱k∥2absent1𝑟𝑛11𝑟𝑛41𝑞subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐱𝑘2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{r(n-1)}\left(1-\frac{r}{n}\right)4(1+q)\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2} (232)
≤1r​(n−1)​(1−rn)​4​(1+q)​{n​σ2​τ​η2+τ​η2​∑i∈[n]∑t=0τ−1∥∇f​(𝐱k,t(i))∥2}.absent1𝑟𝑛11𝑟𝑛41𝑞𝑛superscript𝜎2𝜏superscript𝜂2𝜏superscript𝜂2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝑡2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{r(n-1)}\left(1-\frac{r}{n}\right)4(1+q)\left\{n\sigma^{2}\tau\eta^{2}+\tau\eta^{2}\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f\left({\mathbf{x}}^{(i)}_{k,t}\right)\right\rVert}^{2}\right\}. (233)

9 Additional Numerical Results

To further illustrate the practical performance of the proposed FedPAQ method, in this section we provide more numerical results using different and more complicated datasets and model parameters. The network settings, communication and computation time models remain the same as those in Section 5. The following figures demonstrate the training time corresponding to the following scenarios:

  • •

    Figure 2: Training time of a neural network with four hidden layers and more than 248248248K parameters over 101010K samples of the CIFAR-10 dataset with 101010 labels.

  • •

    Figure 3: Training time of a neural network with one hidden layer over 101010K samples of the CIFAR-100 dataset with 100100100 labels.

  • •

    Figure 4: Training time of a neural network with one hidden layer over 101010K samples of the Fashion-MNIST dataset with 101010 labels.

Similar to Section 5.2, in all of the above scenarios, the data samples are uniformly distributed among n=50𝑛50n=50 nodes. We also keep the communication-computation ratio and the batchsize to be Ccomm/Ccomp=1000/1subscript𝐶commsubscript𝐶comp10001C_{\texttt{comm}}/C_{\texttt{comp}}=1000/1 and B=10𝐵10B=10 respectively, and finely tune the stepsize for every training.
